meanings.def: a glass or plastic container, usually round with straight sides and a narrow neck, used especially for storing liquids
examples: a wine/beer/milk/water bottle
Put the top back on the bottle.
a plastic/glass bottle
To open the bottle, you twist and pull out the stopper.
He threw his message in a bottle into the North Sea.
She filled the bottle with water.
a crowd of youths throwing bottles and stones
Several bags of broken glass bottles were collected.
He threw his empty beer bottle on the ground.

meanings.def: the amount contained in a bottle
examples: He drank a whole bottle of wine.
He handed me a bottle of beer.
We discussed the problem over a bottle of wine.
We washed the food down with a bottle of cheap red wine.
After his wife died, he really hit the bottle (= started drinking heavily).

meanings.def: a bottle used to give milk to a baby; the milk from such a bottle (used instead of mother’s milk)
examples: It's time for her bottle.

meanings.def: courage or confidence, for example to do something that is dangerous or unpleasant
examples: It took a lot of bottle to do that.
I didn’t think she’d have the bottle to ask him.

meanings.def: to do something that has a big effect and after which it is very difficult or impossible to go back to how things were before
examples: When guns were invented, the genie was let out of the bottle.

idioms.idiom: let the genie out of the bottle
idioms.def: to do something that has a big effect and after which it is very difficult or impossible to go back to how things were before
examples: When guns were invented, the genie was let out of the bottle.

meanings.def: to put a liquid into a bottle
examples: The wines are bottled after three years.

meanings.def: to put fruit or vegetables into glass containers in order to preserve them
examples: Keep your empty jam jars for bottling next year’s fruit.

meanings.def: to not do something, or not finish something, because you are frightened

idioms.def: to not do something, or not finish something, because you are frightened
